@dubeejw - some comments
- IMHO - Use cobra as much as possible for argument processing.  Piggybacking moving the httpClient initialization away from init time... the httpClient initialization can be contained in a single `Pre*Run` cobra command function.  See https://github.com/spf13/cobra#prerun-or-postrun-hooks.  This way, commands not needing httpClient support would not have the overhead of initializing a httpClient.
- I recommend that parseArgs() focus solely on parsing arguments and that the setup() (was init()) function should be called outside of parseArgs()
- Remove the `\n` character from the errMsg strings - the string used to create the error objects.  See commands.go line 37
Rebased and merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/e1cc7d22452cd909089c5c7a15d2ac58ca353c6e.

Merging this creates a circular dependence. The catalog is currently not Travis tested against openwhisk, is it? What's the plan for guarding against a breaking change in the catalog affecting our Travis builds in openwhisk?

> not vice versa.

Isn't it true that openwhisk will install the catalog from the other repo? If so, then openwhisk depends on catalog and catalog depends on openwhisk. Hence the circular dependence.
@csantanapr, :+1: :+1:

@markusthoemmes So... about that DB migration üòè Do you have any pointers on where I should start looking for that?

I suppose another option might be to leave all existing actions alone, and have a `kind` of "nodejs" always mean "Node 0.12". This is only a problem when you look at things through the lens of the CLI where a `kind` of "nodejs" is sugar for the current default Node runtime.

Option 3 would be to have "nodejs" continue to always mean "Node 0.12" both in the CLI and in the OW backend. This removes the "nodejs" alias behavior @sjfink was looking for, but makes everything consistent both in the front and back end, and requires no DB migration for existing actions. Instead of an alias, the default Node runtime could be selected by not explicitly specifying a `kind` for .js actions. For example:

``` sh
$ wsk action create MyAction someCode.js
```

IMHO Option 3 sounds pretty good. Thoughts?

It just takes a long time to build all the cli for different operating systems, like mac, linux, windows, etc.
Our travis CI only takes 10 mins as the timeout, so it always fails within 10 mins without finishing the build. Anyone knows how to extend the timeout?

sjfinks-MacBook-Pro:openwhisk sjfink$ docker-machine -v
docker-machine version 0.7.0, build a650a40
The pair issue in openwhisk-catalog: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-catalog/issues/24
Blocked by #748.

I personally suggest to remove the install script in openwhisk. The openwhisk-catalog will pull openwhisk repo for the catalog installation tests each time the code is changed.

I also prefer to split catalog installation from the installation of openwhisk. Now we are trying to install everything when we install openwhisk, which I think there is a potential to improve.

Installation of OpenWhisk can be abstracted into a general project or somewhere we feel comfortable (like the role of devstack plays in openstack). It may install the openwhisk core(we can define late what it means), it may install the catalogs, it may install third party action... The role is to be responsible for deployment.
@rabbah the fact that I must re-run prereq.xml when my docker-machine is restarted should be documented with the docker-machine instructions, I think.

It is - https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/tree/master/ansible#install-prerequisites

> Caveat: Mac users who have a docker-machine setup will have to re-run this playbook every time the boot2docker machine is rebooted. This is because installed prereqs are not persisted on TinyCore Linux.

I have suggested a workaround to @lehoanganh @domdom82 so that we don't need this step in the future (which is an improvement).
I suggest repeating the instruction on the page that describes docker-machine stuff.
I further suggest moving this content to somewhere under docs/
@mdeuser, how about now?

I like the idea of keeping the installation of OpenWhisk as a separate entity. The current ansible approach is confusing, and it supports only simple and specific deployment scenarios. In addition to that the building and installation are too connected. We should be capable of building and producing artifacts (as docker images) and use the same images for different deployment scenarios.
PG 675

@dubeejw and @mdeuser.
This is the PR that I have run into some travis ci issue.
I add the docker build of all the go cli binaries in ansible, because I was not able to access the docker container any more in ansible. This docker build takes a long time. Travis CI will fail if it takes more than 10 mins, which is not enough for the build to finish.

Since gradle comes before ansible. If we can copy all the binaries already built out of the docker, we should be able to access them later in ansible. This can be an approach for us to save the build in ansible.
@dubeejw @markusthoemmes - Thanks for your comments.  I think have have addressed them all now ;-)

@sjfink FYI.

Main comment: agree with RR that this should be staged into 2 commits via a global flag -- first commit everything with global flag python == true, so the change is "Just" a refactoring with no intended semantic change.    After that build passes, we can switch the global flag and thus switch from python to go.
The good news is that prior PRs have enabled the building of the Go binaries inside the `gradle distDocker` builds.  Everyone now has a python and Go binary in their local builds.

Note that the commits aren't in order because [GitHub just doesn't like rebases](https://help.github.com/articles/why-are-my-commits-in-the-wrong-order/). The last three commits are orthogonal changes, though, so it shouldn't affect reviewability.
